content:
University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 31 to 40. Nanoscience in Istanbul https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/december/nanoparticles-in-istanbul Leicester establishing exchange link with leading nanotechnology centre. Chris Binns from our Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Research Group has recently returned from a trip to Turkey, laying the groundwork for a formal link between the University of Leicester and Fatih University.

Fatih is a relatively new university, established 15 years ago with 12,000 undergraduates \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd ten per cent of them from abroad \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd spread across two campuses in Ankara and Istanbul. What particularly attracted our CMP researchers was the university\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds multidisciplinary nanoscience centre which is planning to become a full-on nanotechnology institute with teaching and research programmes.

All lectures at Fatih are presented in duplicate: once in Turkish and again in English. Course work may also be submitted in either language so it is possible to study entirely in English, entirely in Turkish or, if you want to show off, in a mixture of both tongues.

Leicester students will be able to use the Erasmus European exchange programme to visit Fatih University and take advantage of the institution\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds cutting-edge nanotechnology labs as well as the other excellent campus facilities (not to mention the Istanbul nightlife!).

Our CMP group, which is part of our Department of Physics and Astronomy, conducts research into the relationship between atomic configurations, electronic structure and function with a particular interest in the structural and electronic properties of semiconductor nanostructures and the electronic properties of magnetic nanoparticles.

Inside the nanoscience centre at Fatih University
]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Condensed Matter Physics International Physics Magazine:Student 2011-12-22T12:55:00Z Blog Entry Public lecture on energy, environment and climate change https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/november/public-lecture-on-energy-environment-and-climate-change Former Chancellor considers conflicting needs of people and planet on 11 November. The former Chancellor of the University of Leicester, Sir Peter Williams CBE, FREng, FRS, returns to the campus on Friday 11 November 2011 to present a public lecture on: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdEnergy, Environment and Climate Change: Irreconcilable Conflict or Global Opportunity?\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The tragic events earlier this year in Japan underlined the somewhat precarious balance between the needs of a growing global population for energy and the possibility of adverse consequences for the environment and humanity when this balance is disturbed, in this case by a natural disaster leading to technological failure.

The aftermath of events at Fukushima led, predictably, to calls for a curb on nuclear power generation, but this stance is at odds with the simultaneous drive for low carbon energy sources to combat the potential threats due to global warming. What do we know with certainty about such threats and how can we reconcile all these apparently conflicting pressures without a na\ufffd\ufffdve appeal to technologies which today do not even exist?

This talk will draw on recent Royal Society reports on topics as diverse as bio-fuels and geo-engineering and will also emphasise not only the scale of the challenge facing us, but the tremendous economic opportunities which could result from successful attempts to mitigate climate change. 

As well as his duties here, Sir Peter\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds current/former positions include Chairman of the National Physical Laboratory, Vice President and Treasurer of the Royal Society, President of the Institute of Physics, President of the British Association for the Advancement of Science and Chairman of the Engineering and Technology Board.

Jointly organised by our College of Science and Engineering and the Haldane Society, the lecture is free and open to all, with refreshments provided afterwards. It will take place in the Ken Edwards Building*, Lecture Theatre 1, starting at 6.30pm.

For more information please contact: Vicky Orson-Wright, vow@le.ac.uk, 0116 2522142 or Dr Emma Bunce, ejb10@ion.le.ac.uk, 0116 2523541

*NB. The lecture is being delivered by Peter Williams but is not in the Peter Williams Lecture Theatre.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Environment Magazine:Staff Physics Magazine:Student Public lecture 2011-11-03T17:32:38Z Blog Entry From truncheons to TASERs: public lecture on 'less lethal weapons' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2011-archive/april/from-truncheons-to-tasers A free public lecture on Tuesday 12 April explores the science behind weapons that are designed to incapacitate but not kill. Around the world, police officers - even those who carry guns - generally try to avoid killing people wherever possible. So there is a surprisingly large global market for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdless lethal weapons\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd; that is, devices designed to restrain, scare away or cause temporary pain to wrongdoers.

The next public lecture from the Leicester Physics Centre is a fascinating talk by Dr David Wilkinson from the Institute of Physics on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Physics of Not Killing People\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. This is an area that Dr Wilkinson knows better than most folk because for several years he worked at the Home Office Scientific Development Branch*, the Government body responsible for testing and evaluating the wide range of non-lethal weapons produced by companies worldwide.

Less lethal weapons (there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds a fairly obvious reason why the term \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnon-lethal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd is generally avoided) include devices designed to restrain a person, which could be as simple as a net or as complex and impractical as a high-pressure jet of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsticky foam\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (great for stopping someone running away, less helpful afterwards when you\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdre trying to cuff them and get them into a van\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd).

Water cannons are a well-known less lethal weapon, designed to disperse crowds, but are rarely used in the UK. As Dr Wilkinson explains, this is a simple matter of urban geography: water cannons are actually very vulnerable vehicles which require a surrounding cordon of riot police, the water jet blasting above their heads. This is a practical proposition in big squares and plazas, but British rioters very inconsiderately tend to cause their civil unrest in relatively narrow streets.

Then there\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds the TASER**, invented in 1974, which fires two wires at a miscreant and zaps him with electricity. The intention is to hurt him sufficiently that he falls over and is too bothered about the (temporary) pain to resist arrest. Dr Wilkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds illustrated lecture includes some memorable video footage of macho American cops testing TASERs on each other and finding out how much they really hurt.

Some of the photos in Dr Wilkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds lecture are a tad on the gruesome side so this event isn\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt recommended for small children, but for everyone else it\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds an utterly fascinating, very educational \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and in places quite entertaining - look into a largely undocumented field where science meets law enforcement.

The lecture, which is free and open to all, takes place in the Ken Edwards Building, Lecture Theatre 1, at 6.30pm on Tuesday 12 April 2011. Please use the online booking form to be sure of a seat,

  • Department of Physics and Astronomy
  • Lecture poster (PDF)

*Renamed last week as the Centre for Applied Science and Technology

**Incredibly, this stands for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThomas A Swift\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Electric Rifle\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. We are not making this up.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Physics Magazine:Student Public lecture 2011-04-08T10:50:42Z Blog Entry Is it magic? Is it science? Or a bit of both? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2010-archive/may-2010/is-it-magic-is-it-science-or-a-bit-of-both Arthur C Clarke once said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAny sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd A public lecture on 1 June will tread similar ground. Magician and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdself-confessed science fan\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Phill Smith will present The Physics of Magic, the Magic of Physics as the latest in a series of public lectures organised by the Leicester Physics Centre, part of our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

The first half of the talk will show how science is used as the basis for classic magic tricks, and the second half will demonstrate how current advances in physics are approaching what we might consider magic. Which brings us back to Clarke\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Law, above.

Smith has been performing magic professionally for a number of years as well as devising tricks for other performers and writing specialist books. He says:

Magic is the art of exploiting hidden knowledge to enact the impossible. Physics is the science of studying and quantifying the possible. A solid knowledge of physics can help with the mechanisms and hidden concepts that underpin much of magic.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

The lecture is in the Bennett Building, Lecture Theatre 1, at 6.30pm on Tuesday 1 June. All are welcome.

  • University press release
]]> No publisher mjs76 Lecture Physics 2010-05-25T16:21:12Z Blog Entry Klaus von Haeften's Research Page https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/physics/research/cmp/academic-staff/kvh6/personal-research-page Since its first liquefaction almost hundred years ago helium has fascinated researchers because it shows macroscopic quantum effects in its condensed phases. Since I started research I have been interested in the properties of helium clusters and helium droplets - condensed phases that contain a few up to millions of helium atoms. One aspect of my research concerns electronically excited states. The helium atom is the simplest of all many-electron atoms. A fundamental questions that strikes me is how electronically excited states become modified when an excited helium atom is placed near one, two or more helium atoms in the ground state. I tackle this problem using molecular beams of clusters and droplets of helium which allow their size to be varied, and synchrotron radiation to produce electronic excitations. Helium clusters in molecular beams are always liquid allowing to probe disordered arrangements of helium atoms.

Another aspect of my research on helium is the interaction of molecules with helium. Rovibrational spectra show that molecules embedded in superfluid 4He droplets rotate as if they were free, however, their rotation is somewhat slower than in vacuum. This difference in rotational speed reflects the interaction with the helium environment. My interest is to investigate these sometimes very subtle interactions using new spectroscopic approaches that are currently under development in my group. With these new techniques we expect to be able to investigate, for instance, the effect of\ufffd\ufffd thermodynamic phase changes, the on-set of superfluidity and resonances with local and global excitations.

More recently, I have started investigating small clusters and nanoparticles of elements of technological relevance. In the focus are iron and silicon nanoparticles generated by using a range of innovative approaches developed in our group. We co-deposit silicon clusters with water vapour onto a cold target, melt the ice and obtain an aqueous suspension with exceptional optical stability: the clusters emit blue fluorescence in liquid water and show no signs of degrading. We also investigate the interaction with surfaces. AFM measurements of drops of silicon clusters placed on HOPG in ultra high vacuum show predominantly cluster heights of less than 1.5 nm and various forms of self-organisation.

Peer Reviewed Published Papers

Many of my papers can be found with Google and Google Scholar. Google also displays links to pdf files that are accessible through the Leicester Research Archive (LRA) at http://lra.le.ac.uk.

]]> No publisher nb101 Physics ppublications 2010-05-06T12:40:00Z Page Dr Richard White https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/physics/people/richardwhite/template

Postdoctoral Researcher

BSc (Hons)\ufffd\ufffdin Physics with Astrophysics, PhD in High-Energy Astroparticle Physics (University of Leeds)

Tel: 0116 223 1385

Email: rw141@le.ac.uk

Office: F19b, Physics & Astronomy building

Lab: L003, Michael Atiyah Annex

Biography

Dr Richard White graduated from the University of Leeds in 2003 with a first class BSc degree in Physics with Astrophysics winning the departmental prize excellence in experimental physics. Richard stayed in Leeds and completed his PhD in Astroparticle Physics in 2007 working on the gamma-ray observatory VERITAS. After a short postdoctoral research position in Leeds working on the design study for the proposed underwater neutrino detector, KM3NeT, Richard moved to industry. As part of a research and development team at Avacta Richard worked on several projects including a Raman imaging system capable of detecting a droplet of liquid explosive from a moving vehicle for the Ministry of Defence.

In 2009 Richard was awarded an STFC Postdoctoral Fellowship and moved to Leicester in 2010. During his fellowship Richard held the position of Camera Coordinator for the Small Size Telescopes of the\ufffd\ufffdfuture gamma-ray observatory CTA (see below) and was made a visiting research at the University of Oxford. In 2012, Richard was co-investigator on a successful grant to develop the\ufffd\ufffdCompact High Energy Camera (CHEC) for CTA.

Research interests

I am an experimental astroparticle physicist working in the field of gamma-ray astronomy. My research involves the development of instrumentation to probe some of the most violent phenomena in the Universe, from super-novae remnants to relativistic jets and black holes.

I am work on design and prototyping for the\ufffd\ufffdCherenkov Telescope Array (CTA), an ambitious project to build the next generation gamma-ray observatory consisting of more than 100 telescopes. Over 1000 scientists and engineers across 27 countries are involved in CTA. My contribution to CTA is primarily through the development of the Compact High-Energy Camera (CHEC), a UK, US, Japan, Dutch collaboration to prototype an ultra-fast camera to probe the highest energy gamma-rays, up to several 100 trillion electron volts.

I am the CHEC Project Manager and also play a leading role in the technical development of the instrument. When I am not in the lab, I work on understanding the (some time potential) gamma-ray emission from a variety of astrophysical sources using the LAT instrument onboard the Fermi gamma-ray satellite. I also spend time investigating some of the potential mysteries that CTA could address, including testing Einstein\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds theory of relativity with the most energetic photons in the Universe, and hunting for sources of particle acceleration in our galaxy to energies far beyond what is possible on Earth.

Professional Activities

In 2013 I was appointed Secretary of the Institute of Physics Astroparticle Physics Group.

Science Communication

I am actively involved with communicating my work to a wider audience. I have prepared gamma-ray themed posters, movies and instrument demonstrations and presented them to the public at the 2013 and 2014 BBC Stargazing Live events hosted at the University of Leicester. I took part in series of podcasts about gamma-ray astronomy (available\ufffd\ufffdhere). I designed and built the CTA-UK website, now hosted here in Leicester, and I am also involved in communication with industry for CTA photosensors and electronics.

Selected Publications

  • M. Fairbairn, A. Nilsson, J. Ellis, J. Hinton, and R White, The CTA Sensitivity to Lorentz-Violating Effects on the Gamma-Ray Horizon,\ufffd\ufffdeprint arXiv:1401.8178 (2014)
  • K. L. Dutson, R. J. White, A. C. Edge, J. A. Hinton, and M. T. Hogan, A stacked analysis of brightest cluster galaxies observed with the Fermi Large Area Telescope, Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, vol. 429, pp. 2069\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2079 (2013)
  • S. Ohm, J. A. Hinton, and R. White, \ufffd\ufffd-ray emission from the Westerlund 1 region, Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, vol. 434, pp. 2289\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd2294 (2013)
  • E. Nezri, R. White, C. Combet, J. A. Hinton, D. Maurin, and E. Pointecouteau, \ufffd\ufffd -rays from annihilating dark matter in galaxy clusters: stacking versus single source analysis, Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, vol. 425, pp. 477\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd489 (2012)
  • M. Actis et al., Design concepts for the Cherenkov Telescope Array CTA: an advanced facility for ground-based high-energy gamma-ray astronomy, Experimental Astronomy, vol. 32, pp. 193\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd316 (2011)
Full publications list
]]> No publisher tk74 Physics and Astronomy CTA Gamma-ray Physics Astronomy Astrophysics 2009-09-01T11:40:00Z Page Natural Sciences at the University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/interdisciplinary-science/welcome-to-the-centre-for-interdisciplinary-science

Welcome to the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Natural Sciences programmes where you learn science by carrying out research from day one!

These programmes are delivered by The Centre for Interdisciplinary Science. You will be taught by a core team of experienced teachers as well as leading researchers from across the fields of biology, chemistry, physics and earth sciences.

Our\ufffd\ufffdgraduates have gone into academic\ufffd\ufffdand industrial research and a range of employment opportunities in science communication, consultancy, management in scientific industries and teaching. Explore our website and learn how you too can engage with contemporary science and real-world research.

Pre-2014, the Natural Sciences degree was titled Interdisciplinary Science; you may see this name in older literature.

]]> No publisher ams22 University of Leicester Leicester Natural Sciences Science Natural Science Nanoscience Interdisciplinary science I-Science University Undergraduate Biology Chemistry Earth Sciences Natural Sciences plus Combined Science Integrated Sciences Physics 2008-09-09T12:35:00Z Page Ancient Egyptian Astronomy https://www2.le.ac.uk/Members/sls25/index The homepage of Sarah Symons Papers

My most recent paper, which is a re-appraisal of diagonal star tables (or "star clocks") is available here:

A Star\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Year: The Annual Cycle in the Ancient Egyptian Sky

Courses

I give talks, workshops, and study weekends on Egyptian astronomy and also hieroglyphics.\ufffd\ufffd I teach an undergraduate module on archaeoastronomy in the Interdisciplinary Science degree programme.

\ufffd\ufffd

  • Office Hours: Thursdays 10 - 11 am
  • Biography: I studied Physics at the University of Hamburg and graduated with a Diploma in 1995 and a PhD in 1999. I worked at the Max Planck Institute for Flow Research, the German Electron Synchrotron DESY and the University of Bochum before being appointed in Leicester.
  • Research Interests: my research areas are fundamental properties and applications of quantum fluids, clusters and nano-structured material
  • List of peer-reviewed publications
  • Research Projects: (i) impulsive alignment of small molecule-helium clusters; (ii) fluorescence spectroscopy of single molecules in liquid helium; (iii) nanoparticle formation via deposition of metals onto liquid jets and supersonic cluster beams.
  • Enterprise: founder of NANOTX Ltd.
  • Collaborations: Nelly Bonifaci and Frederik Aitken, CNRS, Grenoble; Andrew M. Ellis, and Shengfu Yang, University of Leicester;\ufffd\ufffd Tim Laarmann, DESY, Hamburg; Robert E. Zillich, University of Linz; Marius Lewerenz and Mirjana Mladenovic, University of Paris; Tamar Seideman, Northwestern University; Karl-Heinz Meiwes-Broer, University of Rostock; Arnaud Rouzee, Max Born Institute.
  • Supervision of PhD sudents: (i) Atea Akraiam; (ii) Hanieh Yazdanfar; (iii) Luis Guillermo Mendoza Luna; (iv) Mumin Ko\ufffd\ufffd; (v) Gediminas Galinis; (vi) Mike McNally; (vii) Nagham Shiltagh and (viii) Oliver Youle
  • Available PhD themes: Interactions of nanoclusters in liquids and on surfaces/ metal particle growth at the gas-liquid interface, nanoparticle refinement for industrial application, molecular interactions in quantum fluids at the nanoscale
  • Teaching: (1) opt.1609 1st year Introduction to Nanophysics (2) PA2900 2nd year Labs in general physics, (3) opt.294 2nd year Electronic Labs, (4) opt.2910 2nd Year Grep (Measuring Nanoaerosols), (5) 3rd Year I-Sciences, (6) 3rd year projects, (7) 4th year projects, (8) opt.4621 4th year Nanostructures and (9) Experimental Methods in Nanoscience (postgraduate lecture)\ufffd\ufffd Blackboard.
  • Outreach: Artemis - the superfast XUV laser, fluorescent silicon nanoparticles
  • Other: Organisation of CMP seminars, CMP representative of Equality and Diversity Working Group (EDWG)
